src:
Pronadjen najstariji primerak uspravnog majmuna

06 Nov 2019, 22:20

Ostaci skeleta drevnog majmuna, nadjeni u bavarskoj glinenoj jami, navode na zaključak da su preci današnjih ljudi počeli da stoje uspravno milionima godina ranije nego što se do sada mislilo, naveli su danas naučnici.Medjunarodni tim naučnika je naveo da je deo fosilizovanog skeleta muškog primata, koji je pre skoro 12 miliona godina živeo u vlažnim šumama na jugu Nemačke, veoma sličan kostima današnjih ljudi. U radu objavljenom u časopisu "Nejčr" (Nature), oni su izneli zaključak da je do sada nepoznata vrsta, nazvana "Danuvius gugenmozi", mogla da hoda na dve noge ali i da se penje poput majmuna.To otkriće "postavlja fundamentalna pitanja o našem dosadašnjem razumevanju evolucije velikih majmuna i ljudi", rekla je Madlen Beme, rukovodilac projekta.Pitanje kada su majmuni razvili hod na dve noge okupira naučnike još otkako je Čarls Darvin prvi ustvrdio da su oni preci ljudi. Prethodni fosilni nalazi majmuna koji su hodali uspravno, nadjeni na Kritu i u Keniji, bili su stari do šest miliona godina.Beme, zajedno s naučnicima iz Nemačke, SAD, Kanade i Bugarske, ispitala je više od 15.000 kostiju pronadjenih na arheološkom nalazištu Hameršmide, oko 70 kilometara zapadno od Minhena.Od nadjenih ostataka su uspeli da sklope cele skelete četiri primata koji su živeli pre 11,62 miliona godina. Najpotpuniji kostur, odraslog mužjaka, pokazuje da je životinja bila visoka oko jednog metra, teška 31 kilogram i da je izgledala slično današnjem bonobou, podvrsti šimpanze."Bilo nam je neverovatno kada smo shvatili koliko su neke kosti slične ljudskim, za razliku od kostiju velikih majmuna", rekla je Beme.Naučnici su, zahvaljujući stanju nekoliko dobro očuvanih kostiju, uspeli da rekonstruišu kretanje "Danuviusa" i zaključe da je taj primat, iako je mogao da se rukama drži za grane i visi s njih, mogao i da ispravi na noge i hoda uspravno."Ovo menja naše vidjenje rane ljudske evolucije, da se sve dešavalo u Africi", navela je Beme.Ipak, za razliku od ljudi, "Danuvius" je imao snažan nožni palac kojim je mogao da se stopalom uhvati za granu i bezbedno hoda kroz krošnje.Fred Spur, paleontolog iz londonskog Muzeja prirodnjačke istorije, kaže da su nalazi uzbudljivi ali da će verovatno biti tema mnogih debata, ne najmanje jer dovode u pitanje mnoge postojeće ideje o evoluciji."Ovo je fantastičan materijal. Nesumnjivo će biti mnogo toga što će moći da se analizira", rekao je Spur, koji nije učestvovao u istraživanju.

The oldest specimen of an upright monkey found

06 Nov 2019, 21:20

The remains of an ancient monkey's skeleton found in a Bavarian clay pit suggest that the ancestors of today's humans began to stand up millions of years earlier than previously thought, scientists said today. , who lived in the humid forests of southern Germany nearly 12 million years ago, very similar to the bones of today's people. In a paper published in the journal Nature, they concluded that a hitherto unknown species, called "Danuvius gugenmozi", could walk on two legs but also climb like a monkey. The discovery "raises fundamental questions about our understanding of the evolution of great apes and humans so far, "said Madeleine Beme, project manager. Asking when monkeys developed a two-legged gait has been occupying scientists ever since Charles Darwin first claimed they were human ancestors. Previous fossil finds of monkeys walking upright, found in Crete and Kenya, were up to six million years old.Beme, along with scientists from Germany, the US, Canada and Bulgaria, examined more than 15,000 bones found at the Hammersmide archeological site, around 70 kilometers west of Munich. From the found remains, they were able to assemble entire skeletons of four primates that lived 11.62 million years ago. The most complete skeleton, an adult male, shows that the animal was about one foot tall, weighing 31 pounds and looked similar to today's bonobo, subspecies a chimpanzee. "It was amazing when we realized how similar some human bones are, unlike the bones of large monkeys, "said Beme. Scientists, thanks to the condition of several well-preserved bones, were able to reconstruct the movement of" Danuvius "and conclude that, although he could hold hands and hang from them, the primate could also correct "This changes our vision of early human evolution, that everything was happening in Africa," Beme stated. However, unlike humans, Danuvius had a strong toe that could grasp his foot with a branch. and safely walks through the canopy.Fred Spur, a paleontologist at the London Museum of Natural History, says the findings are exciting but likely to be the topic of much debate, not least as they call into question many existing ideas about evolution. ”This is fantastic material. There will undoubtedly be a lot that can be analyzed, ”said Spur, who did not participate in the research.
